block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''GOOWEN'S BALLOOWINS IN OZ.'' Children 5 and older will join the balloon artist Allynn Goowen, tomorrow at 3 p.m. at the Donnell Library Center, Central Children's Room, second floor, 20 West 53rd Street. Mr. Goowen will bring the story of ''The Wizard of Oz'' alive with props, sets and costumes, all made from balloons. The event celebrates the 100th anniversary of the publication of the book. Free. Information: (212) 621-0638.

''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' presented for the marionette stage by Puppetworks and artistic director Nicolas Coppola, Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. (through Dec. 17) and Monday, Oct. 9 at Puppetworks-Park Slope, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Brooklyn. For children 4 and older. Tickets: $7; $6 for children; $4.50 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations required: (718) 965-3391.

''FAIRY TALES OF THE BROTHERS GRIMY,'' Preston Foerder's puppet show of Grimm's Fairy Tales, in which the puppeteer doesn't show up and the janitor has to take over, using sponges and mops to substitute as characters and scenery. Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 MacDougal Street, between Third Street and Washington Square West. For children 6 and older. Free. Information: (212) 998-5867

''JACK AND THE BEANSTALK.'' The Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater presents an updated version of the classic fairy tale with music, puppetry and comedy, Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m. through Sept. 24 at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, Central Park, West Drive at 79th Street; enter at 81st Street and Central Park West or 79th Street and Fifth Avenue. Admission: $5; $4 for children. Reservations required: (212) 988-9093.

''JOGI AND THE RAINBOW,'' a production by the puppet troupe Backpack Puppets, featuring a puppet boy, dog, cat and a mischievous monkey in a journey to find the rainbow. Tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 a.m. and noon at the Mazur Theater, 555 East 90th Street, between York and East End Avenues. Tickets: $7. Information: (212) 369-8890, Extension 159.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; ages 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''BUTTERFLY AND HUMMINGBIRD TRAIL,'' through Sept. 16 at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights, featuring colorful maps and activity stations where young explorers can search the sky for the garden's colorful winged creatures. Children should also check out the Discovery Garden and Teaching Pavilion for special weekend programs for children 5 to 12. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free with admission: $3; $1.50 for the elderly and students; under 16 free. Free all day Tuesday and on Saturday from 10 a.m. to noon. Information: (718) 623-7200.

''THE HENSON INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL OF PUPPET THEATER'' at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse at 165th Street, tomorrow from 3 to 6 p.m. Performers include Batoto Yetu, a Harlem-based children's puppet troupe, in a dancing and drumming program, and the Machito orchestra, an Afro-Cuban music troupe. There will also be art workshops and storytelling. Information: (718) 681-6000, Extension 145.

''THE KITCHEN NEIGHBORHOOD STREET FAIR,'' tomorrow from 2 to 5 p.m. (rain date is Sunday), at 19th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues, including food, art displays, interactive events and performances. Performing on the main stage in front of the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, beginning at 2:15 p.m. will be Conjuto Placer, an eight-piece Latin ensemble featuring Freddie Dejesus, the puppeteer Preston Foerder with his production of ''Punch and Judy'' and music by a swing music ensemble, the Yalloppin' Hounds. Other activities include walking tours and talks in nearby Chelsea galleries from noon to 6 p.m. Visitors can see the Kitchen's art galleries, with models, miniatures and masks by the puppeteer Ralph Lee. Free. Information: (212) 255-5793, extension 13.

''OPEN HOUSE,'' tomorrow from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the Brooklyn Arts Exchange, 421 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn. Free sample classes and demonstrations in dance, video, theater and creative movement will be available for children 3 to 18. Activities include stage combat (tomorrow at 1:30 p.m.), video (tomorrow at 12:30), musical theater (Sunday at noon) and dance basics for teenagers (Sunday at 1 p.m.). Information: (718) 832-0018.

''SPANISH FOR KIDS,'' a free open house tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. and 11 a.m. to noon at Child's Play East, Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue at 64th Street, offering a preview of classes in the fall for children 2 1/2 to 5, who will learn Spanish through games, singalong songs, puppet shows and educational activities. Classes, which begin Sept. 22 and end Dec. 23, will be offered Fridays at 4 p.m. and Saturdays at 10 and 11 a.m. The classes are $250 for a semester. Registration required for the open house. Information: (212) 397-0172

''STORY CORNER: WILD HORSES.'' Youngsters can imagine what it's like to ride a horse as fast as the wind in a storytelling session tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the Hall of the Americas, first floor of Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000, Extension 230.

''WHISPERS FROM THE WILD STORYTELLING,'' outdoor storytelling about the rain forest, in English and Spanish, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Everett Children's Adventure Garden, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The event is in conjunction with ''Fiesta de Jardines,'' an annual gardenwide festival of Latin-American music, dance, food and demonstrations, including discussions on Latin American plants. Children's Adventure Garden admission: $3; $1 for children, 2 to 12; free under 2. Garden admission: $3; $1 for children, 2 to 12; free under. Hours: noon to 4 p.m. Information: (718) 817-8700.
Exhibitions

''BABAR AND THE SUCCOTASH BIRD,'' an exhibition through Sept. 30 at the Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, second floor, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, featuring the first new Babar book in seven years, which will be exhibited in the form of 18 original watercolors drawn by the author and illustrator, Laurent de Brunhoff. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (212) 397-0669

''BEADS, BODY AND SOUL: ART AND LIGHT IN THE YORUBA UNIVERSE,'' an exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, through Sept. 17, explores 1,000 years of beaded arts in Yoruba culture. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. the museum will present a workshop on creating objects using beads and fabric, with the artist Valerie Mason. Before the workshop, youngsters will tour two current exhibitions, ''From the Studio: Artists-in-Residence 1999-2000'' and ''Beads, Body, and Soul.'' For children 8 and older. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly. Call to reserve space. Information: (212) 864-4500, Extension 230.

''FROM TENT TO TEMPLE: LIFE IN THE ANCIENT NEAR EAST,'' an interactive exhibition (through Jan. 14) developed by the Jewish Children's Learning Lab, Center for Jewish History, Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330, showing the daily lives of people in biblical times and featuring 28 interactive learning stations. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free with admission: $6; the elderly and ages 5 to 12, $4; under 5 and members, free.

''REPTILES: REAL AND ROBOTIC,'' including an alligator-snapping turtle 10 times life size and a Western diamondback rattlesnake 36 feet long, are part of the exhibition and related programs (through Sept. 17) at Science Playground at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Although those animals are robots, the real ones are no less impressive, including gila monsters, bearded dragons and blue-tongued skinks. Related activities include demonstrations and crafts. Hours: Mondays through Wednesdays from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.50; $5 for ages 4 to 17 and the elderly; free for ages children 3 and under; free from 2 to 5 p.m. Thursdays and Fridays. Information: (718) 699-0005.

''TREASURES FROM THE ROYAL TOMBS OF UR,'' an exhibition through Sunday at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, will be the subject of a tour for budding archaeologists of all ages tomorrow at 11 a.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m. Free with admission: $8; $6 for the elderly and students; children 12 and under are free. Reservations advised.Information: (212) 590-0331.
